Yes, the Chinese used specific designs and materials for their military kites during the Song dynasty. They crafted kites with lightweight bamboo frames and covered them with silk or paper. Some kites were designed to have intricate shapes, such as birds or insects, which made them more aerodynamic and stable in flight. 

For example, they used "fishing kites" or "weather kites" to lift heavy loads, which could bear up to 20 people or payloads of 200 pounds. The design of these kites included a strong frame made of lightweight bamboo and a lifting surface of silk or mulberry paper. 

Military kites were also painted with symbols or patterns to indicate their purpose or affiliation. For example, the symbol for the imperial family was often painted on the kites of the Chinese army to show support for the emperor.

Overall, the design and materials used for military kites in the Song dynasty were carefully chosen to ensure they were as effective as possible for their various uses.
